newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electric futures rally on natgas, firm cash.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electric futures rally on natgas, firm cash.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled sharply higher Thursday on surging natural gas prices and firm cash values in the western U.S.
Despite outlook of weather being mild in most of the West next week, the electricity complex leaped toward the upper end of its recent trading range.
In late over-the-counter (OTC) activity, December California-Oregon Border (COB) futures were discussed at $24.50-$24.75 a megawatt hour (MWh), compared with a settlement of $24.83.
January COB finished at $22.25, up $1.25. Deferred COB contracts ended 25 cents to $1.13 higher.
December OTC Palo Verde (PV) futures were talked at $21.80-$22.00, versus a close of $23.00.
January PV finished at $20.25, up 75 cents. Outer PV months ended 65 cents to $1.00 higher.
Daily, peak power prices at COB was assessed late Thursday at $22.50-$22.30, and at PV $20.00-20.50.
The next-day market was bolstered by stronger natgas prices and Bonneville Power Administration withholding offers for Friday.
December gas delivered at the San Juan/Blanco Hub finished the day at $2.49-$2.53 per million British thermal units, compared with Wednesday's range in the $2.36-$2.37.
Natgas prices around the U.S. jumped today on bullish storage data, cold weather in the eastern U.S. and rumor of a problem at the Gulf Coast pipeline.
Most brokers and marketers expected the electricity complex would take cue from gas prices.
